subject: Pass requested networks to scheduler filter_props
commit_message:
Pass requested networks to scheduler filter_props

In Icehouse, the nova-scheduler still had a primary responsibility
in orchestrating a VM's deployment and, as such, had access to the
requested_networks via the schedule_run_instance(...) method. In Juno,
we've switched to a model in which the conductor takes over more of
this capability and only invokes the scheduler's select_destination
method.

As a result, the scheduler no longer has any way to determine
which networks are being requested, leaving schedulers unable to
determine which networks the user is requesting at deploy time since
there are no other associations formed at this time.

This patch sends the requested_networks along to the scheduler's
select_destinations() method via filter_props['requested_networks'],
thus allowing schedulers to interrogate this information at VM
initial deploy time.

Change-Id: Ie3fcaeabd1d4074c1157cc0592021c26bc24e2d3
Closes-Bug: #1363568

subject: Eventlet green threads not released back to pool
commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection.
Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Add a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout
behaviour. Allows closing idle client connections after a period of
time, eg:

$ time nc localhost 8776
real    1m0.063s

Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

DocImpact:
Added wsgi_keep_alive option (default=True).
Added client_socket_timeout option (default=900).

SecurityImpact

Conflicts:
        keystone/common/config.py
        keystone/common/environment/eventlet_server.py

NOTE: This is not 1:1 cherry-pick because 'eventlet_server' config
group is not present in juno.

Closes-Bug: #1361360

subject: Improve provision VLAN performance
commit_message:
Improve provision VLAN performance

The VLAN provisioning performance can be sped up by querying only for
the CNAs of the VM that the request is for.  The device_id can be used
for this data - as that matches the nova instance UUID.

This is valuable in scenarios where there are hundreds of VMs on the
system.  Rather than having every request query the entire system, this
change allows us to only get the data that we need for the request that
comes in.

This change required bundling together data from both the neutron port
and the device detail.  As such, a new entity called NetworkDevice was
added that pulls together these two pieces of information.

commit_message:
Reflect provider change in puppet-openstacklib

With the creation of the new openstack_config provider, some processing
that was done in swift_config has been centralized in
openstack_config.

Impacted methods are :

  * section
  * setting
  * separator

Also, this commit adds the fact that, when passing a specific string
(ensure_absent_val) the provider will behave as if ensure => absent was
specified. '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' is the default value for
ensure_absent_val.

The use case is the following :

swift_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => 'bar' } # will work as usual

swift_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' } # will mean absent

That means that all the current :

if $myvar {
  swift_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }
} else {
  swift_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : ensure => absent }
}

can be removed in favor of :

swift_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }

If for any reason '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' turns out to be a valid value for
a specific parameter. One could by pass that doing the following :

swift_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>',
ensure_absent_val => 'foo' }

subject: lxc: fix disk_info passed to _create_domain_and_network in _hard_reboot
commit_message:
lxc: fix disk_info passed to _create_domain_and_network in _hard_reboot

Commit a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c changed
_get_instance_disk_info to return a list rather than a json string.  As
part of that, it overwrote the local disk_info variable (which was a
dict) in _hard_reboot before it was passed to
_create_domain_and_network.  Eventually when disk_info gets down to
_create_domain_setup_lxc it fails the _is_booted_from_volume because
it's a list rather than a dict.

This moves the _get_instance_disk_info call in _hard_reboot within the
context.auth_token block since the return value is otherwise not needed,
and creates a unique local variable for the instance disk_info so it
doesn't collide with the disk_info that comes back from
blockinfo.get_disk_info.

At some point we should create objects for these various disk_info
variables because otherwise it's really confusing trying to track the
types and usage of all of these different things called 'disk_info'
which are sometimes dicts and sometimes lists of dicts.

Closes-Bug: #1370590

W/o this patch, the most of the OCF agents
sending their own logs to nothere.

This is a major issue, because we want to
be able troubleshoot and keep OCF events
in syslog and collected at remote logs
server(s) as well.

The solution is to enable HA_LOGTAG and
HA_LOGFACILITY for each OCF script shipped
with the Fuel.

DocImpact: Ops guide. Logging events from
Fuel OCF agents will be collected both
locally in the /var/log/daemon.log and remotely,
with the file names based on the agent "foo-agent"
name as the "ocf-foo-agent.log". Note, that the
RabbitMQ will continue to log its OCF events
to the lrmd.log due to backwards compatibility reasons.

Sphinx and OpenStack documentation standards require the use of

git mv $FILE.md $FILE.rst

subject: Fix race conditions in config overrides tasks
commit_message:
Fix race conditions in config overrides tasks

    * Convert configuration casts into blocking calls and move them
      from the task manager to the API. Update the Trove records
      only after a successful update on the guestagent.

    * Change the way how we apply the configuration changes.

       - On attach: Apply the values dynamically only if all of them
                    can be applied at once. Put the instance into
                    the 'RESTART_REQUIRED' state otherwise.
       - On detach: Apply the values dynamically only if:
                    a) Default values for all of them are
                       available in the configuration template.
                    b) All values can be applied at once.
                   Put the instance into the 'RESTART_REQUIRED'
                   state otherwise.

    * Remove override template resolution. Pass override values in a
      Python dict (like it is for 'apply_overrides').
      The user-provided configuration values do not get resolved and
      are applied as supplied by the user - hence no need for a template.
      It also avoids the need to double-parse the overrides in
      guestagents that do not support configuration imports.

    * Moved MySQL-specific value conversions (K, M, G suffixes)
      down to the MySQL guestagent.

    * Update the MySQL 'update_overrides' methods to accept both
      Python dicts and rendered strings. This is for backwards
      compatibility with older task managers that send overrides as
      a string.

    * Remove deprecated methods from the taskmanager.

Re-calculate resource usage for suspend/resume

Problem: The bug is the resource usage on database will not be updated
         after suspend/resume action. This will lead to the host
         resource cannot be reused after suspending instance(s)
         Refer bug 1402502 for details.

Solution: Update resource usage when suspend/resume is successful.
          And add a protection on resume action to avoid resource
          over-commitment on the host machine.

Detail: 1, Modify nova.compute.manager.ComputeManager. At the end of
           Suspend/Resume, call _instance_update() to update resource
           usage.

        2, Modify nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker. Use a
           dict to record the suspended instance. Skip suspended
           instances during resource statistic procedure.

        3, Modify nova.compute.api.API. Invoke new RPC resume_instance()
           inside nova.conductor.manager.ComputeTaskManager, which will
           finally invoke RPC resume_instance() in
           nova.compute.manager.ComputeManager as previous.

        4, Add resume_instance() inside nova.conductor.ComputeTaskManager
           It will check original host capacity by invoking RPC call
           select_destinations() in nova.scheduler.host_manager.client

        5, New keywords 'suggested_nodes' and 'suggested_hosts' are added
           for selecting destination. With both keywords, nova.scheduler
           will firstly select hosts/nodes included in suggested_nodes
           or suggested_hosts. Then nova.scheduler will check the host
           capactiy. If no host has capacity to start the vm, NoValidHost
           exception will be thrown.

Impacted methods are :

Also, this commit adds the fact that, when passing a specific string
(ensure_absent_val) the provider will behave as if ensure => absent was
specified. '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' is the default value for
ensure_absent_val.

The use case is the following :

sahara_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => 'bar' } # will work as usual

sahara_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' } # will mean absent

That means that all the current :

if $myvar {
  sahara_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }
} else {
  sahara_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : ensure => absent }
}

can be removed in favor of :

sahara_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }

If for any reason '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' turns out to be a valid value for
a specific parameter. One could by pass that doing the following :

sahara_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>',

subject: Generate unique names for service queue
commit_message:
Generate unique names for service queue

RabbitMQ supports such feature as temporary
queues with autogenerated names, it means that when you
define a queue, you leave the name empty, so RabbitMQ generates
a unique name with "amq.gen-" prefix, after fixing a bug [1]
with heartbeats, we got working reconnects in case of connectivity
issues. When reconnect happens, for queues with autogenerated
names RabbitMQ behaves strangely, it does not delete previous queues
but creates new one, so for a single worker there is old/not
used queue and the new one. When new message comes to exchange
it has 50% chance to get into working queue. If there more
reconnects happen, more dead queues are created and we have
less chance to get message in working queue.

In order to prevent that, each worker should have unique
name for its service queue, which it will use during worker's
life time. When reconnect happens, it will try to connect to
the same queue which was used before.

RabbitMQ version: 3.3.5
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1483182

Closes-bug: #1485895

subject: vmware: use cache_prefix to preserve cache directory
commit_message:
vmware: use cache_prefix to preserve cache directory

Currently value of `my_ip' config option is used as image cache dir
prefix to prevent races between nova-compute instances using the same
datastore.

The common practice of making nova-compute (with vmwareapi driver
chosen) HA is to have it run in active/passive mode controlled by
Pacemaker.  In that case Pacemaker can move nova-compute instance to
another host, should something happen to the original one, which
effectively will cause change of the IP address - thus, all cached
images will have to be re-downloaded again, despite the fact they are
still there in the datastore and still belong to this particular
nova-compute instance.

I02e758af19cf3a652a5c39d02904e73a1088fe60 made it possible to use the
`cache_prefix' config option to denote, which cache directory should
be used by a particular nova-compute instance. As long as we set the
same `cache_prefix' value for all nova-compute processes running in
active/passive mode, the cache directory will be the same on every
host.

Closes-Bug: #1482121
